false_positives.context: Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___ Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___ Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M Service: MEDICINE Allergies: No Allergies/ADRs on File Attending: ___ ___ Complaint: Dyspnea Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: Evaluation for airway stent History of Present Illness: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a history of epigoltic squamos cell carcinoma diagnosed ___ ___ s/p chemo/radiation completed ___ ___, adenocarcinoma of stage IV left lung diagnosed ___ s/p cycle 3 of 5 of chemo completed on ___ who was found to have new tracheal tumor at the level of the carina causing worsening dyspnea who is transferred to ___ for evaluation of airway stent. The patient originally presented on ___ to ___ with progressive dyspnea and worsening cough. He reports worsening SOB x 1 month and intermittent episodes of cough productive of clear to yellow sputum. Denies hemoptysis. He was found to have sepesis secondary to bilateral pneumonia and sepsis. The patient was started on vanc/cefepime/azithromycin. He decompensated with hypotension and was transferred to ICU and diflucan was added. With Abx and fluid resusitation he improved. Course complicated by thrombocytopenia and was diagnosed with HIT with positive antibody assay. Diflucan d/c prior to transfer to ___. Heparin was d/c and plts improved. The patient then developed acute on chronic renal failure with a creatinine of 4. 4 (baseline 1. 3-1. 5) and was transferred on hospital day ___ (___) to ___ for possibility of dialysis. While at ___ patient has been afebrile and blood cultures negative. Per report OSH cultures showed blood culture of strep viridans and MSSA ___ sputum. On day ___ of vanc/cefepime on day of transfer. The patient had UOP of 2L/day and dialysis was not required per renal team. While at ___ patient had worsening dyspnea despite treatment of pneumonia. Additionally, patient had coughing fits with hemoptysis. Concern for PE and was started on agatroban. He then had a low probability V/Q scan and negative bilateral lower extremity ultrasounds and argatroban was stopped. CT chest revealed continued bibasilar opacities with new tumor causing airway narrowing above carina. The patient was placed on 10L highflow NC however continued to experience respiratory distress requiring a course of BiPAP and then weaned to again to 10L highflow NC. On exertion or movement the patient desats to 89-90%. HR has been stable ___ ___, BPs 130s/70s, RR ___. Per report the patient understands stenting would be palliatve measure and is transferred for stent. The patient was on 10L highflow NC with saturations >93% on transfer. On arrival to the MICU, the patient reports that he feels ok. He states that his SOB is about the same throughout his course. He continues to have a cough productive of clear to yellow sputum. He complains of pain ___ his right shoulder and over his buttocks. Reports right shoulder pain is chronic from rotator cuff problem and developed buttock pain ___ hospital from lying

Enlarged heterogeneous prostate gland. 4. 11 mm enhancing focus in the right hepatic lobe may represent a hemangioma. 5. 4 mm pulmonary nodule does not require additional follow-up if patient is at low risk for primary lung neoplasm. If patient is at high risk for primary lung neoplasm, optional follow-up CT chest could be performed in 12 months. Chief Complaint: painless jaundice Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: ERCP with sphincterotomy and plastic biliary stent History of Present Illness: PCP: (confirmed with patient, notified on admission by fax) Name: ___. Location: ___ ___: ___, ___ Phone: ___ Fax: ___ Admission ___ 2130 CC:painless jaundice ___ with pmhx of ___ noticed weight loss a few weeks ago. The patient's PCP checked ___ and noted abnormalities. US confirmed presence of obstructing mass. in the interim developed significant jaundice. Was sent to ___ clinic appt ___) and was found to have a very high bilirubin and was sent to the ER for evaluation. He has no s/s of RUQ pain, fever/chills, nausea/vomiting. Other than some mild fatigue, the patient is completely asymptomatic. In ER: A CT confirmed the findings of a mass. mets vs. cholangiocarcinoma most likely dx. HEENT: No conjunctival pallor, ++ scleral jaundice, OP clear CV: RRR no audible m/r/g Lungs: clear to auscultation Abd: soft, NT, normal BS Ext: No C/C/E Neuro: Gait, strength and sensation intact bilaterally. Pertinent Results: CT ABD/PELVIS IMPRESSION: 1. Marked intrahepatic biliary dilatation. Diffuse infiltrative mass in the majority of the right lobe of the liver, incompletely assessed on this single phase study. This may be consistent with cholangiocarcinoma or metastatic disease. 2. CHEST (PA & LAT) UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION: ___ year old woman with sob ___ s/p lap right nephrectomy) REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: r/o acute process Final Report EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT) IMPRESSION: The lung volumes are normal. Borderline size of the cardiac silhouette with minimal fluid overload. On both the frontal and the lateral radiograph, there is blunting of the left costophrenic sinus, suggesting the presence of a small left pleural effusion. Subsequent areas of left basilar atelectasis are present. No pneumonia, no pneumothorax. SURGICAL PATHOLOGY REPORT - Final PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSIS: Right kidney, laparoscopic radical total nephrectomy: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma, conventional type, see synoptic report. Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ was admitted to Urology with a RIGHT renal mass after undergoing robot-assisted laparoscopic right radical nephrectomy. No concerning intraoperative events occurred please see dictated operative note for details. The patient received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis. The patient was transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable condition. On POD0, pain was well controlled on PCA, hydrated with intravenous fluids keeping urine output at over >30cc/hour. She provided with pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis. On POD1, the patient was transitioned from PCA to oral medications with the advancement to clears diet. She poorly tolerated the narcotics which caused dizziness, nausea and a general "unwell" feeling. She did not have emesis but did experience periorid nausea. This limited her cooperation with early mobilization and deep inspiration, incentive spirometry use. She is known to have obstructive sleep apnea and was maintained on telemetry for continuous oxygen saturation monitoring and provided CPAP and nasal canula use for overnight. She was given additional pain medications and anti-emetics and subsequently ambulated and advanced to clears with toast and crackers. She was not given Toradol because of her POD1 creatinine. At her request her narcotics were adjusted. Basic metabolic panel and complete blood count were checked daily. On POD2 her pain was moderately well controlled ranging from ___. Ms. ___ ambulated and continued to use the incentive spirometer. She was able to ambulate on room air without requirement of supplemental oxygen to keep her saturation greater than 92%. She did not feel well enough to go home and remained overnight.

Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ is an ___ yo woman with a  h/o Coumadin anticoagulation and Alzheimer's who presented with weakness, slurred speech, and RUE swelling and was found to have an INR 20, sublingual hematoma, and RUE hematoma. # Increased INR: Her supratherapeutic INR was most likely due to receiving 7. 5mg instead of 2. 5mg daily of Coumadin, per family interview about home dosing of coumadin. It remained unclear for how long the wrong dosing had been occurring. It was also possible that interaction with Bactrim or other medication (memantidine most recently new) or changes in diet may have further complicated her coagulopathy. Interaction with Bactrim seemed unlikely given time course of elevated INR (INR 2 wks ago was supratherapeutic at 3. 5. ) In anticipation of the need for a transfusion, she was typed and crossed for 2 units PRBCs on admission. 4 units of FFP were given on arrival to the ICU, and she had also received 10mg IV Vit K in ED. After these therapies, her INR came down to 1. 3. She was tranfered out of the ICU on the day after admission, and she was restarted on her home dose of coumadin. On hospital day 3 (___), her INR had increased to 2. 2, which was greater than had been expected for a single administration. It was decided that resuming coumadin therapy should be addressed by her PCP on an outpatient basis. On the day of discharge, her INR was 3. 3.

ACUTE ISSUES: ============== #DILATED NON-ISCHEMIC CARDIOMYOPATHY #HFrEF EF 15% The patient presented with a ___ year history of chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea, found on echo to have HFrEF ___ dilated cardiomyopathy with EF of 15%. He was trialed on both spironolactone and digoxin while inpatient, but ultimately these were stopped secondary to persistent hyperkalemia. NEISSERIA GONORRHOEAE (GC), NUCLEIC ACID PROBE, WITH AMPLIFICATION :Negative for Neisseria Gonorrhoeae by PCR.. ___ URINE CULTURE: URINE CULTURE -w/MIXED BACTERIAL FLORA ( >= 3 COLONY TYPES), CONSISTENT WITH SKIN AND/OR GENITAL CONTAMINATION. Brief Hospital Course: In summary, the patient is a ___ female who presented with 1 week of worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea.. # Abdominal Pain/Diarrhea: After an extensive imaging and lab work-up the patient's abdominal pain etiology was still unclear. Work-up data with transvaginal ultrasound, abdominal & pelvic CT, vaginal swabs, and blood labs all essentially ruled out endometriosis, fibroids, ovarian cysts w/torsion, ectopic pregnancy, GC/Chlamydia, appendicitis, kidney stones, colon pathology. Despite her benign gynecologic lab/imaging workup she had some mild tenderness on pelvic exam at her cervix. Thus, she was treated empirically for PID with Doxycycline and Cefotexan and advised that if this pain did not resolve or if she noticed any unusual odor, discharge or bleeding that she needed to follow-up with her primary care physician or see ___ gynecologist as soon as possible.. Ultimately, based on the temporality and description of watery diarrhea it was felt that Ms. ___ have been experiencing a form of viral gastroenteritis, though the prominent abdominal pain was fairly atypical. Moreover, viral gastroenteritis is frequently associated with brief elevations in lipase which was noted with Ms. ___ labs with a lipase of 99. Pancreatitis was unlikely as her symptoms appeared to quickly resolve and she was able to tolerate a regular diet well within hours of her admission. Abdominal CT also showed no radiological signs of pancreatitis. Initially, vasculitis was considered but felt to be less likely based on normal ESR and guaiac negative stool. A rarer cause such as porphyria was briefly entrtained but this is usually more chronic, relapsing abdominal pain, often with neurological symptoms which the patient lacked. Lastly, the team considered IBD as an etiology given the component of diarrhea, but this was also doubted as IBD usually presents less acutely with a more chronic course.. Upon admission she was initially placed on clear liquids but soon advanced to a regular diet which she tolerated very well with no additional diarrhea or vomiting and very minimal nausea. She was given additional IVFs for basic rehydration. For abdominal pain control she was given low doses of IV Dilaudid and then switched to PRN oral oxycodone. Compazine was given for nausea relief and Ativan was also given for dual anxiety and anti-nausea effects. Stool cultures and labs were ordered but the patient's diarrhea seemed to have abated after admission. She stated that she was not usually able to go to the bathroom in hospitals and had "trouble" feeling comfortable enough to have a bowel movement. Unfortunately, as sample was not collected but given the patient's desire to be discharged and her rapid clinical improvement she was not kept in the hospital simply to collect these studies. She was told, however, that if her diarrhea returned that she should return to the ED or call her primary care provider as stool studies would be an important part of the workup. At time of discharge home she was pain free and her nausea was nearly gone. She had no residual cramping or emesis either and she appeared much more alert and hydrated with moist mucous membranes and a less pallid complexion. She was asked to continue Tylenol as needed OTC for a week for any residual abdominal pain but not to exceed 3g/day.. # Anxiety - During her hospital course she was given Ativan ___ mg PO every 4 hours as needed for anxiety. She denied any suicidal or homicidal thoughts but seemed to have a sad, flat affect. She reported no hallucinations or changes in her eating or sleeping habits. She described her mood as "steady" but explained she still got sad at times. She explained that she felt she did not need her Klonopin anymore so she had gradually tapered herself off of it over a period of ___ weeks. She took

false_positives.context: (patient with high fevers and rigors rising concern for bacteremia and ___ positive blood cultures) vs tick-borne illness (negative parasite smear) vs. malignancy (in the setting of retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy) vs. secondary to rheumatologic process. Arthrocentesis performed in the ___ showed right knee with 40,000 WBC and 16,000 RBC and left knee with 32,000 WBC and 2200 RBC. Though this was not quite in range for septic arthritis, it was felt to be possible since she did reiceve one dose ceftriaxone at ___ before arhtrocentesis was performed in ___. Due to suspicious for septic arthritis, she was empirically covered with vancomycin and ceftriaxone from ___ while awaiting culture data. Her arthrocentesis gram stain and culture remains negative, however, and ___ blood cultures positive from ___ with coagulase-negative staphylococcus, which was felt to represent contamination. Due to unusual presentation of bilateral joint effusions concerning for spetic arthritis, she underwent TTE to rule out endocarditis however this showed no vegetations. She was also seen by Rheumatology consult. Multiple lab tests for Rheumatologic work-up were sent (e. g. ___, anti-dsDNA, ___, anti-CCP antibody), but none came back positive. Infectious Disease consultation recommended discontinuing antibotics, which was done on ___. She was afebrile off of antibiotics, and range of motion in both knees improved over time, as did her strength (of note, CK was WNL). She did have a very elevated CRP, however, with low ESR, in conjunction with prominent effusions of both knees, which was puzzling to all teams in terms of elucidating the etiology of her illness. Her effusions and pain limited her mobility, so she worked with Physical Therapy to improve her strength and balance. Overall, she likely had post-infectious arthritis (inciting source is unclear, but her history is notable for a likely viral-prodrome) her response was somewhat consistent with viral-mediated vs reactive arthritis. She had been afebrile for multiple days on discharge, and was not requiring analgesia. She was asked to use tylenol and NSAIDs for pain control, and follow-up with Rheumatology as an outpatient. # Rash: Patient presented with a rash consisting of erythematous, non-pruritc macules and papules spread over her anterior chest and her extensor surfaces, especially on her upper thighs. This was felt to be likely a viral exanthem given diffuse involvement without pruritus in setting of acute illness vs. drug rash in setting of exposure to cephalexin (given eosinophilia and improvement once cephalexin was stopped). This was not a typical plaque with eczematous rash as can be seen in reactive arthritis, or in sun-exposed areas as would be seen in lupus. Possibilities also included salmonella rash (light pink, over anteiror chest near shoulder), but stool culture was negative. On discharge, her rash was resolving and beginning to fade. # Thrombocytopenia: Admitted with placelet count of 118. Likely decreased production due to viral illness versus acute infection. No splenomegaly on recent imaging. Thin and thick smear negative for parasite. No spherocytes or schistocytes on smear. Resolved on discharge. # Normocytic anemia: Patient is a menstruating female, but arrived with hemoglobin of 11. 6 on admission. Iron studies were consistent with anemia of chronic disease, especially given ferritin > 90. No evidence of schistocytes on smear. This was trended and stable. # Retroperitoneal Lymphadenopathy: Noted on CT at ___ done on ___. This was felt to be mild and non-specific. While it is rare, hematologic malignancy (lymphoma) can present with retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. Her LDH was normal, and HIV negative.

false_positives.context: 4. Beaded appearance of the mid and distal cervical internal carotid arteries suggestive of fibromuscular dysplasia, stable. Renal Ultrasound: IMPRESSION: Mild right hydronephrosis, slightly improved from the prior CT without visualization of the right ureter. Flex Sigmoidoscopy: There was erythema, congestion, friability, and ulceration up to 35 cm, which was the extent of evaluation. Cold forceps biopsies were performed for histology at the colon and rectum. Colon BX: Mucosal biopsies: A. Rectum biopsy: Chronic active colitis with ulceration. B. Random colon:  Florid chronic active colitis with ulceration (multiple pieces). Note: No granulomas seen. Brief Hospital Course: #Colitis: Patient was transferred from OSH with ___ loose, watery bowel movements over the previous 24hrs and increasing lethargy and somulence. A CT scan on admission was notable for pan-colitis. WBC was elevated to 32 and there was strong clinical suspicion for C. diff colitis. She was started on PO vancomycin, vancomycin enemas, IV flagyl, and tigecycline and admitted to the surgical ICU. She was intubated for airway protection and transiently required levophed for systolic blood pressure in 60's. She received 10L of fluid resuscitation. Her symptoms improved with antibiotics and she was extubated within 24hrs without complication. First 2 Cdiff studies in addition to stool studies returned negative and antibiotics were narrowed. However, when PO vancomycin and IV tigeclycine were stopped her WBC count jumped and diarrhea worsened. Given clinical suspicion for infectious process, specifically cdiff, she completed a a 14 day course of PO vancomycin. After several days of hospitalization, patient developed several loose bloody bowel movements. Given negative stool studies, decision was made to perform flex sigmoidoscopy with bx showing changes suggestive of ulcerative colitis. She was started on mesalamine 1600mg PO TID with improvement of symptoms. Presentation was most likely secondary to ulcerative colitis with superimposed bacterial colitis which initially improved with antibiotic therapy. She will follow up with gastroenterology for further management of ulcerative colitis. #R IJ clot: She was found to have right arm swelling several days after right internal jugular central catheter placement. false_positives.context: colateral circulation. There was no evidence of an acute coronary occulsion. During the next few hours, the patient continued to have VT/VF which was refractory to aggressive therapy. He was shocked over 30 times on the day of admission and he received repeated cycles CPR, his electrolyte abnormaties were corrected, and anti-arrhythmic medications were administered, including lidocaine and amiodarone. The patient was hypotensive and placed on 3 pressors. The patient also had IABP and pacer wires placed in the cath lab. Eventually, the patient settled into NSR. The patient was weaned off lidocaine and given a loading dose of amiodarone. He had several days without recurrance of his VT however, on hospital day ___, he had recurrance of treatment refractory VT and despite multiple resuscitation efforts, the patient passed away on ___ at 1700. # Anoxic brain injury: It was estimated that the patient had ___ minutes without a perfusing cardiac rhythm prior to EMS arriving on the scene. He did not get any CPR during this time. The patient had signs of severe CNS injury with a bleak prognosis (decerebrate posturing babinski, dilated pupils that were minimally reactive, oculocephalics not intact) most likely anoxic brain injury. He was not felt to be a good candidate for cooling as it is a pro-arrhythmogenic and the patient presented with refractory VT. Head CT was negative for an acute intracranial bleed. The patient was noted to have tongue twitching which at first was concerning for seizures however, neurology felt it was most consistent with myoclonic jerks from anoxic brain injury. EEG showed an encephalopathy without seizure activity. Neurology was planning to reevaluate the patient's neurologic status and further discuss prognosis on hospital day 7 however, the patient passed away prior to that re-evaluation.. # Cardiogenic shock: It was felt that his cardiogenic shock was most likely secondary to an arrhythomia. He was treated with IVF, pressors and an IABP. Eventually, the patient was weaned off pressors however, he intermittently required dopamine for blood pressure support while getting propofol for sedation to syncronize the patient with the ventilator. His IABP was d/c'ed on hospital day 2. An echocardiogram showed severely depressed LVEF at 20%. The patient had LV and apical akinesis and was initiated on a heparin gtt for prophylaxis against a ventricular thrombus.. # Respiratory Failure/Ventilator Associated Pneumonia:  The patient was intubated and difficult to oxygenate initially. He was found on chest CT scan to have collapse of his Left lower lobe. He most likely had an aspiration event during his arrest. He spiked a fever and had copious repiratory secretions that were positive for bacterial pneumonia. His sputum cultures grew pseudomonas. He was initially treated with broad spectrum antibiotics but they were narrowed as culture data returned. The possiblitiy of PE was considered, however, CTA was not obtained because of the patient's renal function. PE was felt to be less likely as the patient's hypoxia improved with aggressive suctioning and treatment of his pneumonia. Furthermore, he was anticoagulated for his apical akinesis and therefore was receiving treatment for PE.. # Acute renal failure: The patient most likely had worsening of his chronic kidney disease from lasix and ace inhibitor prior to admission. This may have caused his hyperkalemia. After the patient's cardiac arrest, he developed ATN and required CVVH to manage his uremia.. # Shock liver and pancreatitis:  The patient had evidence of injury to mulitple organ systems including his liver and pancreas secondary to cardiogenic shock.. # Diabetes: The patient's diabetes was managed with an insulin gtt initially and then an insulin sliding scale. Medications on Admission: glyburide 5mg bid metformin 1000mg bid lipitor 80mg daily

IF you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of pain medicine. Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises. If you experience any of the folloiwng, please contact your surgeon: - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours - pain that is getting worse over time - pain accompanied by fever of more than 101 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain MEDICATIONS: Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as you did before, unless you have been told differently. He started taking Motrin with good results, however the pain continued to escalate. Patient presented to ED at ___ on ___, he reports he received a dose of IV antibiotics and was sent home. Colonoscopy on hospital day 2 revealed ___, but very little active bleeding. Following the procedure, he developed chest pressure in the setting of rapid atrial fibrillation (HR to 140s) and EKG with diffuse ST segment depressions. He was transferred to the ___ Care Unit, where he received IV Cardizem and digoxin, with subsequent reduction resolution of chest pressure and reduction in HR and conversion to sinus rhythm over ___ hours. Troponins peaked at 1. 8. EKG on the morning of transfer was reportedly essentially at baseline without ST segment changes. He is now transferred to ___ further management, including cardiac catheterization and/or Persantine thallium study. On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. false_positives.context: Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___ Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___ Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F Service: MEDICINE Allergies: Fosamax Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: Chest pain, fever Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: EGD History of Present Illness: The patient is a ___ year-old female with Crohns Disease and a history of breast cancer s/p bilateral mastectomy, radiation and chemotherapy who presented to her primary care physician 2 days ago with fever to 101, mild abdominal pain, and increased diarrhea (above what she experiences with her Crohns). At that time, she denied nausea or vomiting but noted a loss of appetite and poor oral intake. She also noted persistent pleuritic chest pain since that morning that felt like her GERD. No relief wtih Nexium and Maalox. She notes mild diaphoresis, but no shortness of breath, lightheadedness, dizziness, shoulder or arm pain. The patient's gastroenterologist recommended a CT of the abdomen, which the patient declined. Labs drawn at her PCP's office were remarkable for Amylase and Lipase of 123 and 192 respectively. Yesterday, the patient's pain was not improved, and her gastroenterologist recommended evaluation in the emergency department. There her chest X-ray was negative, CTA was negative for PE, EKG was not significantly changed, no pericardial fluid was seen on beside ultrasound, 1 set of cardiac enzymes were negative and the patient was able to ambulate comfortably. Amylase and lipase were added on to her labs but she declined to wait for the results. They returned at 120 and 90 respectively. This morning, she had recurrent epigastric/substernal chest discomfort described as sharp, worse with deep breaths, better lying down. She was refered again by her PCP to the ___.. In the ___, her amylase and lipase were found to be further elevated. She received a RUQ. She was made NPO.. Of note, the patient started 6 mercaptopurine for treatment of her Crohns Disease about 2 weeks ago. Past Medical History: PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - breast cancer status post bilateral mastectomy, radiation and chemotherapy. Status post bilateral reconstruction. She has chronic pain syndrome secondary to this. - Crohn's disease c/b toxic megacolon in ___ - pancreatitis ___ - chronic foot pain - osteopenia. PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: myomectomy, cholecystectomy, lumpectomy

Patient reports that he received the flu vaccine in ___ and two weeks later he developed flu like symptoms with fever, chills, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. He slowly improved over 6 weeks however continued to complain of fatigue. Last week he went to the ___ clinic and labs were notable for a white count of 21K. In the ED, initial VS were T 99. 3, HR 108, 132/71, RR 18, 100% RA. Labs notable for a white count of 26K, Hb 9. 4, PLT 471, lactate 2. 3, Cr 1. 9 (baseline 2. 0 ), HCO3 18. CXR showed IMPRESSION: Multifocal nodular opacities in the left upper lobe can represent bronchopneumonia. Irregular opacities in the lingula have a more chronic appearance may be the sequelae of prior infection. If prior imaging is available for comparison, the images can be reviewed and an addendum dictated. Otherwise follow-up chest radiograph in 4 weeks is suggested to ensure resolution. On arrival to the floor, patient reports he feels well. He denies any pain, cough, or shortness of breath. He notes that about 1 week ago he developed URI symptoms with sore throat and cough associated with body aches noting he believes he had the flu. Brief Hospital Course: In summary, the patient is a ___ female who presented with 1 week of worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea.. # Abdominal Pain/Diarrhea: After an extensive imaging and lab work-up the patient's abdominal pain etiology was still unclear. Work-up data with transvaginal ultrasound, abdominal & pelvic CT, vaginal swabs, and blood labs all essentially ruled out endometriosis, fibroids, ovarian cysts w/torsion, ectopic pregnancy, GC/Chlamydia, appendicitis, kidney stones, colon pathology. Despite her benign gynecologic lab/imaging workup she had some mild tenderness on pelvic exam at her cervix. Thus, she was treated empirically for PID with Doxycycline and Cefotexan and advised that if this pain did not resolve or if she noticed any unusual odor, discharge or bleeding that she needed to follow-up with her primary care physician or see ___ gynecologist as soon as possible.. Ultimately, based on the temporality and description of watery diarrhea it was felt that Ms. ___ have been experiencing a form of viral gastroenteritis, though the prominent abdominal pain was fairly atypical. Moreover, viral gastroenteritis is frequently associated with brief elevations in lipase which was noted with Ms. ___ labs with a lipase of 99. Pancreatitis was unlikely as her symptoms appeared to quickly resolve and she was able to tolerate a regular diet well within hours of her admission. Abdominal CT also showed no radiological signs of pancreatitis. Initially, vasculitis was considered but felt to be less likely based on normal ESR and guaiac negative stool. A rarer cause such as porphyria was briefly entrtained but this is usually more chronic, relapsing abdominal pain, often with neurological symptoms which the patient lacked. Lastly, the team considered IBD as an etiology given the component of diarrhea, but this was also doubted as IBD usually presents less acutely with a more chronic course.. Upon admission she was initially placed on clear liquids but soon advanced to a regular diet which she tolerated very well with no additional diarrhea or vomiting and very minimal nausea. She was given additional IVFs for basic rehydration. For abdominal pain control she was given low doses of IV Dilaudid and then switched to PRN oral oxycodone. Compazine was given for nausea relief and Ativan was also given for dual anxiety and anti-nausea effects. Stool cultures and labs were ordered but the patient's diarrhea seemed to have abated after admission. She stated that she was not usually able to go to the bathroom in hospitals and had "trouble" feeling comfortable enough to have a bowel movement. Unfortunately, as sample was not collected but given the patient's desire to be discharged and her rapid clinical improvement she was not kept in the hospital simply to collect these studies. She was told, however, that if her diarrhea returned that she should return to the ED or call her primary care provider as stool studies would be an important part of the workup. At time of discharge home she was pain free and her nausea was nearly gone. She had no residual cramping or emesis either and she appeared much more alert and hydrated with moist mucous membranes and a less pallid complexion. She was asked to continue Tylenol as needed OTC for a week for any residual abdominal pain but not to exceed 3g/day.. # Anxiety - During her hospital course she was given Ativan ___ mg PO every 4 hours as needed for anxiety. Due to unusual presentation of bilateral joint effusions concerning for spetic arthritis, she underwent TTE to rule out endocarditis however this showed no vegetations. She was also seen by Rheumatology consult. Multiple lab tests for Rheumatologic work-up were sent (e. g. ___, anti-dsDNA, ___, anti-CCP antibody), but none came back positive. Infectious Disease consultation recommended discontinuing antibotics, which was done on ___. She was afebrile off of antibiotics, and range of motion in both knees improved over time, as did her strength (of note, CK was WNL). She did have a very elevated CRP, however, with low ESR, in conjunction with prominent effusions of both knees, which was puzzling to all teams in terms of elucidating the etiology of her illness. Her effusions and pain limited her mobility, so she worked with Physical Therapy to improve her strength and balance. Overall, she likely had post-infectious arthritis (inciting source is unclear, but her history is notable for a likely viral-prodrome) her response was somewhat consistent with viral-mediated vs reactive arthritis. She had been afebrile for multiple days on discharge, and was not requiring analgesia. She was asked to use tylenol and NSAIDs for pain control, and follow-up with Rheumatology as an outpatient. # Rash: Patient presented with a rash consisting of erythematous, non-pruritc macules and papules spread over her anterior chest and her extensor surfaces, especially on her upper thighs. This was felt to be likely a viral exanthem given diffuse involvement without pruritus in setting of acute illness vs. drug rash in setting of exposure to cephalexin (given eosinophilia and improvement once cephalexin was stopped). This was not a typical plaque with eczematous rash as can be seen in reactive arthritis, or in sun-exposed areas as would be seen in lupus. Possibilities also included salmonella rash (light pink, over anteiror chest near shoulder), but stool culture was negative. On discharge, her rash was resolving and beginning to fade. # Thrombocytopenia: Admitted with placelet count of 118. Likely decreased production due to viral illness versus acute infection. No splenomegaly on recent imaging. Thin and thick smear negative for parasite. No spherocytes or schistocytes on smear. Resolved on discharge. # Normocytic anemia: Patient is a menstruating female, but arrived with hemoglobin of 11. 6 on admission. Iron studies were consistent with anemia of chronic disease, especially given ferritin > 90. No evidence of schistocytes on smear. This was trended and stable. # Retroperitoneal Lymphadenopathy: Noted on CT at ___ done on ___. This was felt to be mild and non-specific. While it is rare, hematologic malignancy (lymphoma) can present with retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. Her LDH was normal, and HIV negative.
